div.head:
Embleme 7. Of the Secrets of Nature.
A chicken is flying out of the nest, which falls weeweagaine into the nest.

lg.l: The bird of Jove had nested on a rockerock,
Where weeweShee brought forth, and fed her tender weeweflocke:
Out weeweflyes the eldest having wings and traynetrain,
PulldPulled by the naked nestling weewebacke weeweagaine
To the deserted nest: you weewehitt the weewenayle,
If you know how to weewejoyne them head and weewetayle.

div.head: Discourse 7.
div.ab:
What Hippocrates, the defender and propugnator of Physicians, affirms of hu
mors, that they are different and many in man, and not one weeweonely, otherwise
various diseases, could not arise, that weewewee perceive to be true of the elements
of the world: for if there was but one weeweonely element, there could be weewenoe-
mutation of it into another, weewenoe generation nor corruption, yea all things
would be one immutable thing, and weewenoe meteors, weewemineralls, plants, and
animalls could be naturally from weewetheme produced. For this reason the su
preme Creator composed the whole weewesysteme of this world of weewedivers and-
contrary natures, namely of light and heavy, weewehott and cold, moist and dry-
that one might be affinity weewepasse into the other, and soeso a composition be
made of weewebodyes, which might be very different one from another in essence,
qualityes, virtues, and effects: for in things perfectly mixed are the light Ele
ments, as fire and weeweaire, and weeweallso the heavy, as earth and water, which are soeso
æqually tempered together, that one recedes not from the other, but suffers weeweitselfe
to be easily taken and held by the other as weeweneighbour by weeweneighbour: Earth and weeweaire
are contrary one to the other, soeso fire and water, yea notwithstanding fire main
tainesmaintains weewefreindship with weeweaire by heat weewecomon to both, with earth by siccity: soeso
aire with water, and water with earth: by which means they are all weewejoyned
by bonds of affinity or rather consanguinity, and weewedoe weeweremayne together in
one composition, which, if it abound with the light Elements, elevates the-
heavy with it, if with the heavy, weighs weewedowne the light with it: This is decla
red by the two Eagles, one with wings, the other without, of which that-
which weeweendeavoured to fly is restrained by the other an example hereof is evident
in the fight of the Falcon and Heron, for the Falcon soaring higher in-
the weeweaire by his Speedy flying, takes and tears the Heron with his Talons, by
whose weight both fall to the ground: The contrary appeared in the-
artificiall dove or Automa of Archytas, where heavy things were lifted up
by light, that is, the wooden body of it caryedcarried into the weeweaire by the-
Spirit includes within: In the weewePhilosophicall subject the light things weewedoe
first prædominatepredominate the heavy, as to plenty, but they are overcome by vir
tue of the heavy things, and in processe of time the Eagles wings are cut-
of, and one very great bird (namely an Ostrich) is made of two, which
can consume iron, and which being impeded by weight runnsruns more upon
the earth, than weeweflyes in the weeweaire, though it weewehath goodly wings: Concerning
this or the like Hermes (as the Author of Aurora chapt. 5. affirms) writes thus:
I have considered a bird worthy to be had in estimation by the wise, which
flyes when it is in Aries, Cancer, Libra, or Capricorne, and you will never
faylefail of it in pure mynesmines, and rocky mountains: Concerning the same Se
nior in Tabula, where two are soon, one volatile the other without wings,
whereof one holds the others weewetayle by its beakebeak, that they cannot easily be
seperated: For this is the device and machination of weeweuniversall nature,
allwayes to rayseraise heavy things by light, and likewise to depressedepress light
things by heavy, as the Author of the perfect Magistery declarethdeclares, who
constitutes seven weeweminerall spirits, as it were erratickeerratic weeweStarrs, and-
Discourse 7.
soe many weewemetallicke weewebodyes, as fixed weeweStarrs, and enjoynsenjoins these to be
wedded to those: from weewetheme weeweallso Aristotle the Chymist, the Spirit, weewesayth weewehee,
having dissolved the body and weeweSoule, soeso as to exist in their weeweforme, weewedoth not
remaine a fixed thing, weeweunlesse you operate upon it: now operation is to weewejoyne-
it with the body, from which you weewepræpared it at first: because the Spirit is-
thereby prevented from flight being mixed with the supersistences of the-
body: the light Elements, namely weeweaire and fire, as a learned man declares,
doe in Camphore oversway the heavy; and therefore it is weewesayd wholywholly to ex
hale and evaporate into weeweaire. In Argent vive, the flowers of Sulphur, Anti
mony, the Salt of Harts blood, Sal Armoniacke, and such others, the earth-
flyes with the weeweaire into the AlembickeAlembic, and is not seperated from it. In Gold,
glasse, Diamond, the Stone Smyris, Granats, and the like, the Elements-
doe notwithstanding fire weeweremayne along time weewejoyned without detriment,-
and the earth retainesretains those things which are left in weeweitselfe. In other com
bustibles division and separation of one thing from another is effected, soeso
that the ashes are left in the bottomebottom, the water, weeweaire, and fire fly up
wards: weewewee must not therefore have respect to the unæquallunequal composition of
these last, being not soeso strongly weewemixd, nor to the comixtioncommixtion of the first,
though more durable, yet volatile, but to the solidity, constancy, and fixity
of the weewemidle: for soeso the bird without wings will detainedetain that which weewehath,-
and the fixed substance will fix the volatile, which must necessarily be
done. . . . . . . . . .
